issues.title: Problems verifying the trust relationship between a digital signer and a supplier of a digitally signed object
issues.author: rjb4standards
issues.body:
this information is contained in two articles on Energy Central, but I'll summarize here.
https://energycentral.com/c/ec/we-cannot-secure-software-supply-chain-without-sbom 
https://energycentral.com/c/ec/who-ya-gonna-trust 

Today's digital signing methods allow anyone with a valid signing certificate/key to sign any object, without requiring authorization from the party that originated the artifact. Software consumers have no way to "validate" that a digitally signed object, i.e., Program A produced by supplier S that is signed using a certificate owned by party D is legitimate. Software consumers that need to establish trust in Program A need a reliable method to confirm that Supplier S authorized signer D to sign Program A as part of digital signature verification during a software supply chain risk assessment.  

Current digital signature verification practices only check that the signers certificate is valid and the MAC in the signature matches the computed hash of the signed artifact i.e. Program A (integrity verification), but does not provide any assurance as to the trustworthiness of the relationship between a signer in the digital signature and the supplier of an artifact. Anyone can sign anything today, without authorization from the originator of an artifact and the digital signature verification check will pass.
